Gals\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;5\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0156\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of lens selection techniques. For each method, the number of required <em>Gaia</em> detections, density cut and PMSIG cut is given. All searches also include a <em>Gaia</em> magnitude threshold of <em>G</em> &gt; 15. We note the candidates are not mutually exclusive.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quasar selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>Gaia</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Density<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PMSIG<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>N<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.2\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>&lt;100\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;18\u00a0</td><td>2895\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>&lt;50\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;15\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0274\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.4\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;30\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;10\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0397\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>unWISE model\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Milliquas\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0046\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spec. (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Gravitationally%20lensed%20quasars%20in%20%26lt%3Bem%26gt%3BGaia%26lt%3B%2Fem%26gt%3B%20%E2%80%93%20III.%2022%20new%20lensed%20quasars%20from%20%26lt%3Bem%26gt%3BGaia%26lt%3B%2Fem%26gt%3B%20data%20release%202&amp;publicationDate=2018-12-10&amp;volumeNum=483&amp;issueNum=3&amp;author=Lemon%2C%20Cameron%20A%3B%20Auger%2C%20Matthew%20W&amp;startPage=4242&amp;endPage=4258&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fsty3366&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\"              <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ShareDrop\" class=\"addthis_toolbox addthis_default_style addthis_20x20_style f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div     <li><a class=\"addthis_button_compact\"><span>More</span></a></li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                    <div class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-search-dropdown\">\r\n        <div class=\"mobile-search-inner-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                    <div id=\"MobileMicrositeSearch\" class=\"mobile-microsite-search\">\r\n                        <label for=\"mobile-navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">Navbar Search Filter</label>\r\n class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"dropdown-institution-signout\">\r\n                        </li>\r\n                    </ul>\r\n                </li>\r\n                            <li class=\"site-menu-item\">\r\n                    <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f483%2f3%2f4242%2f5237725\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476670 id=\"129476670\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery and spectroscopic confirmation of 22 new gravitationally lensed quasars found using <em>Gaia</em> data release 2. The selection was made using several techniques: multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections around objects in quasar candidate catalogues, modelling of unWISE coadd pixels using <em>Gaia</em> astrometry, and <em>Gaia</em> detections offset from photometric and spectroscopic galaxies. Spectra of 33 candidates were obtained with the William Herschel Telescope, 22 of which are lensed quasars, two highly probably lensed quasars, five nearly identical quasar pairs, one inconclusive system, and three contaminants. Of the three confirmed quadruply imaged systems, J2145+6345 is a 2.1 arcsec separation quad with four bright images (<em>G</em> \u00a0=\u00a016.86, 17.26, 18.34, 18.56), making it ideal for time delay monitoring. Analysing this new sample alongside known lenses in the Pan-STARRS footprint, and comparing to expected numbers of lenses, we show that, as expected, we are biased towards systems with bright lensing galaxies and low source redshifts. We discuss possible techniques to remove this bias from future searches. A |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20 complete sample of lensed quasars detected by <em>Gaia</em> and with image separations above 1 arcsec will provide a valuable statistical sample of around 350 systems. Currently only 96 known lenses satisfy these criteria, yet promisingly, our unWISE modelling technique is able to recover all of these with simple WISE-<em>Gaia</em> colour cuts that remove \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent of previously followed-up contaminants. Finally, we provide an online data base of known lenses, quasar pairs, and contaminant systems.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: observational&quot;\">methods: observational</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: general&quot;\">quasars: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476672 id=\"129476672\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Pan-STARRS 3\u03c0 survey (PS, Chambers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is expected to have already imaged \u223c2000 lensed quasars with images brighter than <em>i</em>\u00a0= 22 and separated by more than 0.67 arcsec (Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Considering just the extragalactic (|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20) sky of PS (68\u00a0per\u2009cent of the sky), the number drops to \u223c1350. However, we currently know of only 163<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> lenses satisfying the same criteria. Many of the missing lenses will have their multiple quasar images approximately separated by the typical full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the Pan-STARRS PSF. This blending, coupled with the variable source colour, lensing galaxy brightness, and image configuration, creates a plethora of possible pixel patterns, many of which are easily confounded with vastly outnumbering systems such as quasars projected near stars, star-forming galaxies, or even physically distinct quasar pairs. A potential solution to finding all lensed quasars would be to use similar variability between images, as proposed by Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Indeed, the Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) estimate expects detection of the brightest lensed quasars by using the PS yearly stacks rather than the full survey depth. Time-resolved data are currently unavailable, however, and without the auxiliary information from variability, contaminant systems cannot be readily removed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We therefore aim to use <em>Gaia</em> data to help remove contaminants, at the expense of a brighter image threshold. <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s excellent resolution (FWHM \u2248 0.1\u2009arcsec, Fabricius et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and targeting of point sources (Gaia Collaboration <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Prusti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), makes it an excellent discovery survey for bright lensed quasars (Surdej, Claeskens\u00a0&amp; Smette <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Jackson, Ofek\u00a0&amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Finet\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). During its 5 yr mission, <em>Gaia</em> will measure auxiliary information including colours and proper motions for all detections. Proper motions are evidently an effective way to remove contaminant systems containing stars (e.g. Heintz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The first <em>Gaia</em> data release, on 2016 September 14, catalogued known lensed quasars within its brightness threshold, but it rarely catalogued all images (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ducourant et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). The second <em>Gaia</em> data release (GDR2, Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), on 2018 April 25, has a marked improvement in detecting closely separated images, down to 0.4 arcsec (Arenou et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Accordingly, there is a more complete detection of all images of known lensed quasars (Ducourant et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s whole-sky, high-resolution catalogue, several methods have already been explored to mine gravitational lenses as efficiently as possible. Several techniques have been suggested and applied using such a catalogue of positions, including: matching multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections to photometric quasars (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; Krone-Martins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), considering <em>Gaia</em> offsets to SDSS quasar positions (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), or by using the spatial positioning of clusters of point sources that are consistent with simple gravitational lens models (Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Wynne\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Papers I and II in this series developed and applied techniques to discover lensed quasars based on detections in <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s first data release. In this paper we search the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 data base, together with data from WISE, SDSS, and Pan-STARRS, to discover 22 new lensed quasars. The paper is outlined as follows: Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> considers the number of lenses we expect to find given certain constraints on brightness, separation, and survey area using <em>Gaia</em> and Pan-STARRS; Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> presents the <em>Gaia</em> parameters of the known lenses and contaminant systems; Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> outlines our main search techniques, with the results from a spectroscopic follow-up presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a> investigates a population analysis of these new lenses and of known lenses in comparison to a complete mock sample. We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476678 id=\"129476678\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 CURRENT LENS STATISTICS AND LENS DATA BASE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have motivated a search based on the advent of a new data set, but it is prudent to consider what searches have already been made in the Pan-STARRS footprint, what biases exist in these searches, and how many lenses are already known. Since we will present a search based on optical detections, we will consider the lens searches carried out in the optical, though several radio lens searches (e.g. King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) have found lenses with bright optical counterparts. To aid our understanding of the current lens statistics, we have compiled a list of all known published lensed quasars, with information on image separation, source redshift, and relevant publications in an online data base: <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/ioa/research/lensedquasars/</a>. This data base will be continually updated with newly published lensed quasars.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The most extensive optical survey for lensed quasars was the SDSS quasar lens search (SQLS, Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), which yielded 62 lensed quasars (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). This search started from spectroscopically confirmed quasars with 0.6 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 2.2 and an SDSS component brighter than <em>i</em>\u00a0= 19.1. The redshift cut ensured completeness in this redshift range, while at higher redshifts, objects classified as extended were not completely targetted for SDSS spectroscopic follow-up (Richards et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). We expect most small-separation lensed quasar systems with multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections (i.e. <em>G</em> &lt; 20.7 for each image) to be brighter than the SQLS selection limit, particularly when considering the lensing galaxy flux. However, wider separation lenses with the individual components separately catalogued by SDSS might still remain undiscovered. A similar survey conducted for the SDSS-III BOSS quasar sample discovered 13 lenses (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Concurrently with the SQLS search, lenses were found using an infrared-excess from 2MASS (Ofek et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) or using the better quality, redder imaging of UKIDSS (Jackson, Ofek\u00a0&amp; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Jackson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). More recent lens discoveries in Pan-STARRS, SDSS, and VST-ATLAS have yielded several new lenses, through photometric selection (Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), further mining of the SDSS spectroscopic quasar sample (Sergeyev et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shalyapin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), catalogued deblending (Rusu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), or serendipity (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Lucey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We therefore expect that lenses with high-redshift sources or bright lensing galaxies, and fainter systems with large separations, to still be plentiful in the SDSS and Pan-STARRS footprints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To understand the number of lenses that could be mined in the Pan-STARRS footprint with multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections, we use the mock simulations from Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>, and find which lenses on the sky would readily be detected by <em>Gaia</em>. To convert the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a><em>i</em>-band lensed image magnitudes to <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitudes, we use the SDSS spectroscopic quasar catalogue cross-matched to <em>Gaia</em>, so a <em>G</em>\u2212<em>i</em> relation is determined at each redshift. For each mock lens in the catalogue, a <em>Gaia G</em>-band magnitude is synthesized from the matched catalogue based on the source redshift. In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we provide the expected number of lensed quasars with <em>Gaia</em> detections (two for doubles and at least three for quads) in the 21\u00a0039 deg<sup>2</sup> of |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20 sky of Pan-STARRS for several image separations. As there is scatter in the <em>G</em>\u2212<em>i</em> relation, the <em>G</em>\u2212<em>i</em> conversion is repeated for each mock lens 100\u00a0times and thresholds re-applied. This provides the uncertainties in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. We also provide the numbers of <em>known</em> lenses in the |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20 Pan-STARRS footprint that have measured <em>Gaia</em> detections of <em>G</em> &lt; 20.7.</p>                        <a id=\"129476682\" scrollto-destination=\"129476682\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted numbers of lensed quasars. The uncertainties come from the <em>G</em>\u2212<em>i</em> band conversion and shot noise from the size of the catalogue. Following the convention of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>, we include doubles that have both images brighter than the <em>Gaia</em> threshold, and quads with at least three images brighter than this threshold.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Im. Sep.          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476682\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted numbers of lensed quasars. Sep. (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>All<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Quads<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Doubles<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>PS 3\u03c0\u00a0</td><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>352\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>66\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>286\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>G</em><sub>2, 3</sub> &lt; 20.7\u00a0</td><td>&gt;1.0\u00a0</td><td>242\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td><td>46\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>195\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20\u00a0</td><td>&gt;1.5\u00a0</td><td>145\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>119\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2.0\u00a0</td><td>81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>68\u00a0\u00b1\u00a04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2.5\u00a0</td><td>41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a03\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Known lenses\u00a0</td><td>&gt;0.5\u00a0</td><td>94\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>81\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>In PS\u00a0</td><td>&gt;1.0\u00a0</td><td>89\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>76\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>G</em><sub>2, 3</sub> &lt; 20.7\u00a0</td><td>&gt;1.5\u00a0</td><td>61\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2.0\u00a0</td><td>31\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0</td><td>23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>&gt;2.5\u00a0</td><td>17\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476682\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Considering the case of image separations above 1 arcsec, there are 46/195 expected quads/doubles, though we only know of 13/76 such systems. <em>Gaia</em> is very complete for detecting both images of doubles when it should (i.e. when both images are brighter than <em>G</em> \u223c 20.7; see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>), though this might not be true for quads given the increase in local crowding. In both the mocks and known lens numbers, we have included all quads satisfying the maximum image separation, however we have not removed those with minimum image separations less than 0.4 arcsec. This could partly explain the large discrepancy at the smallest image separations.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476684 id=\"129476684\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 <em>Gaia</em> DR2 DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Before searching the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 catalogue for lensed quasars, we investigate how the <em>Gaia</em> parameters can be used to remove common contaminants. As part of this investigation and to aid future lens searches, we have compiled a list of all published, spectroscopically followed-up lensed quasar candidates. This is readily accessible on our online data base, and is intended to both prevent repeated observations, and to allow tests of future lens-finding techniques\u2019 selection purity.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476686 id=\"129476686\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Detection rate</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows the number of images detected by <em>Gaia</em> for the known lensed quasars in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2. We split the sample into doubles and quads, with the latter including all systems with more than two images. Only one quad lensed quasar had four images detected in DR1, SDSSJ1004+4112, a quasar lensed by a cluster with images separated by \u223c15 arcsec (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). There is a dramatic improvement for lensed quasar image detection in DR2, with three\u00a0times more doubles having both images detected. The 24 doubles that have only one image detected are due to the fainter image not meeting the detection threshold. The triple system, APM08279+5255, is the only system of the doubles and triples with two images bright enough for <em>Gaia</em> to detect, yet with only one detection (Irwin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). This is likely due to the small separation of the system \u2013 0.38 arcsec. The improved completeness generally applies to the quads as well. The small number of quads with only one image detected in DR2 demonstrates not only how most quads have at least two bright images of similar flux (either in folds, crosses, or cusp configurations), but also <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s increased detection rate in crowded regions with DR2.</p>                        <a id=\"129476688\" scrollto-destination=\"129476688\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Number of lensed quasars with N <em>Gaia</em> detections in <em>Gaia</em> DR1 and DR2, from a total sample of 206 lenses \u2013 52 quads, 2 triples, and 152 doubles. We include triply imaged systems in the quads column.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR2<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>All<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Quads<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Doubles<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>All<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Quads<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Doubles<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a00\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>105\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0</td><td>27\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td><td>122\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>112\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u2265 4\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a00\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>105\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0</td><td>27\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td><td>122\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>112\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u2265 4\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476688\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p We include triply imaged systems in the quads column.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR1<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR2<span 4\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th colspan=\"3\"><em>Gaia</em> DR1<span aria-hidden=\"true\"
