aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a00\u00a0</td><td>45\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>105\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0</td><td>91\u00a0</td><td>27\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>24\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>50\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td><td>122\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>112\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u00a0=\u00a03\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>5\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>N</em> \u2265 4\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476688\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476689 id=\"129476689\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Proper motions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em>\u2019s precise, multi-epoch photometry also enables proper motions to be measured, and these can be very effective at removing stellar contaminants. Cross-matching SDSS spectroscopic quasars and stars to <em>Gaia</em>, all bright (<em>G</em> &lt; 20) isolated quasars and stars have catalogued proper motions, while only 84\u00a0per\u2009cent of lensed quasar images, also with <em>G</em> &lt; 20, have proper motions. This must be due to the crowding of nearby detections and overlapping windows not yet being processed (Riello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). For all fainter objects (<em>G</em> &gt; 20) this percentage quickly drops to around 50\u00a0per\u2009cent.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Proper motions alone do not help without taking their uncertainties into account. We therefore define the proper motion significance (PMSIG) as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1411118_equ1\" content-id=\"update1411118_equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\textrm{PMSIG} = {\\left[{\\left(\\frac{\\textrm{pmra}}{\\textrm{pmra}\\_\\textrm{error}}\\right)}^2 + {\\left(\\frac{\\textrm{pmdec}}{\\textrm{pmdec}\\_\\textrm{error}}\\right)}^2\\right]}^{{}^{1}\\!/_{2}}, \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where pmra, pmra_error, pmdec, and pmdec_error are obtained from the <em>Gaia</em> DR2 catalogue. The distribution of PMSIG for lensed quasar images, isolated quasars, and stars is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. There are four lensed quasar images with a PMSIG value above 10: QJ0158\u22124325 (Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), DESJ0405\u22123308 (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), RXJ0911+0551 (Bade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), and SDSSJ1330+1810 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The latter three cases are compact quads with nearby collections of quasar images, perhaps leading to <em>Gaia</em> misassigning the images at each epoch due to the required binning of a 2.1-arcsec-wide window perpendicular to the scan direction. However, for the doubly imaged lens, QJ0158\u22124325, the brighter image (<em>G</em> \u00a0=\u00a017.60) has a PMSIG of 13.8 and a small astrometric excess noise (AEN) of 0.7\u00a0mas (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>), with the other image also being detected by <em>Gaia</em> 1.22 arcsec away. It is unclear what has caused this image\u2019s large PMSIG.</div>                        <a id=\"129476692\" scrollto-destination=\"129476692\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=wrtyIOcsTsVXljORIhEx3r1gDsvwAOQSqOrHpUW1ZszQ80Brg9xSseyrqdeQZbzDenjQWPM8NZRsI808FB4co3jZpBOthoRlOZAXMgv6eXUOxbp7fc16rF059DMINEh82R26CwqlDFsQ89-~xxYgSyCDXN1jEpoXvpsIO228Fgo6Dttn3EldNeQRxdcSw6VWELNMTWtRqjPBMgYdhKABkmBhiQNavhoBgqdcUt~C2la9H6R1vdBdWi60Q~7CbKh1O9zLNVnSu16XX8KZQLdl6GyEJkocLZ0G89nwdOAUExUtCAonjriwfpUpTxuajlMDuxRYla4Ce9EdoUAa5~kmuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A histogram of proper motion significances for spectroscopic stars fainter than G\u00a0= 17, spectroscopic quasars, and lensed quasar images. The histograms are scaled to the same peak values.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476692/sty3366fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=S7Ku0HHavLLVYpY05m~BxmgVu7WjevpqAMmBR-jJj8hIF6ZAZfOB-D58FlCyUcp2p8xHMGNFQON-ck8Niw6lUV71zMiim8apD~EV9Hx-5wvmy1onfDUHq3UUcZlybSD8-L-YEfLN~j4qPah30pIMIdxlsFlhUR87crUEiWVi9H5RjiVUGrPl-14BxfgegTmoLyGLrDSWU2c5QLLavvxyXMXYztIy8JIaBKpHLXHRqLwARy0S6sc4jHqc4Vrm7nMOYsU7ogVjUqiQCrVXj8A3k14pp08422yAn5Y11D1yV7e1ogiGTi6EiTIK5nx8O53e8nT55zZaknvTWjH~rjM1Ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476692&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A histogram of proper motion significances for spectroscopic stars fainter than <em>G</em>\u00a0= 17, spectroscopic quasars, and lensed quasar images. The histograms are scaled to the same peak values.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=wrtyIOcsTsVXljORIhEx3r1gDsvwAOQSqOrHpUW1ZszQ80Brg9xSseyrqdeQZbzDenjQWPM8NZRsI808FB4co3jZpBOthoRlOZAXMgv6eXUOxbp7fc16rF059DMINEh82R26CwqlDFsQ89-~xxYgSyCDXN1jEpoXvpsIO228Fgo6Dttn3EldNeQRxdcSw6VWELNMTWtRqjPBMgYdhKABkmBhiQNavhoBgqdcUt~C2la9H6R1vdBdWi60Q~7CbKh1O9zLNVnSu16XX8KZQLdl6GyEJkocLZ0G89nwdOAUExUtCAonjriwfpUpTxuajlMDuxRYla4Ce9EdoUAa5~kmuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A histogram of proper motion significances for spectroscopic stars fainter than G\u00a0= 17, spectroscopic quasars, and lensed quasar images. The histograms are scaled to the same peak values.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476692/sty3366fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476692\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=S7Ku0HHavLLVYpY05m~BxmgVu7WjevpqAMmBR-jJj8hIF6ZAZfOB-D58FlCyUcp2p8xHMGNFQON-ck8Niw6lUV71zMiim8apD~EV9Hx-5wvmy1onfDUHq3UUcZlybSD8-L-YEfLN~j4qPah30pIMIdxlsFlhUR87crUEiWVi9H5RjiVUGrPl-14BxfgegTmoLyGLrDSWU2c5QLLavvxyXMXYztIy8JIaBKpHLXHRqLwARy0S6sc4jHqc4Vrm7nMOYsU7ogVjUqiQCrVXj8A3k14pp08422yAn5Y11D1yV7e1ogiGTi6EiTIK5nx8O53e8nT55zZaknvTWjH~rjM1Ew__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476692&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A histogram of proper motion significances for spectroscopic stars fainter than <em>G</em>\u00a0= 17, spectroscopic quasars, and lensed quasar images. The histograms are scaled to the same peak values.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476693 id=\"129476693\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Astrometric excess noise</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A major contaminant for lens searches relying on photometric quasar selection is compact star-forming galaxies (e.g. Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Upon inspection of ground-based data, a pair of star-forming galaxies can appear consistent with PSFs and worthy of spectroscopic follow-up. <em>Gaia</em> provides a way to remove such systems, through the AEN parameter (e.g. Belokurov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Koposov, Belokurov\u00a0&amp; Torrealba <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). <em>Gaia</em> DR1 showed that the AEN could separate intermediate-to-high-redshift quasars from star-forming galaxies via a simple cut. In the vast majority of cases this also kept all lensed quasar images (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We repeat the <em>Gaia</em> DR1 AEN comparison from Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) for <em>Gaia</em> DR2. From our list of known lensed quasars, there are 321 lensed quasar images with <em>Gaia</em> detections. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> shows <em>Gaia</em> magnitude against AEN for each of these images, and also SDSS spectroscopic quasars, galaxies, and stars. All lensed quasar images clearly avoid the galaxy locus in the <em>Gaia G</em>-AEN plane. When only considering AEN, several lens images have galaxy-like AEN values.</p>                        <a id=\"129476696\" scrollto-destination=\"129476696\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=yjqTR01bUXhqqNOBYTedxrGlbzSYoeVvxUaWAiDSvF7e96OABGAwZYx~aBDX1tDTSddNsxAGhuGFul1HJ7iEfbRlGsE5B~ikLUPRhprm8brpKDiOZqPhVF-gMFqj5XSDvWTMVx7gGNyUMQcj9unqI0DZXpecJua3~jdXWkPrCLpdhXoQBY0pCsfN-PdXpjCzI5jAGLRYrQ5k2-4nIxta6lhzMnX30Cn-mfE60xIvlZFqx8~rZVjaQSc1-44oyuEI3mSb3wM7Sl~FrOQYh30qG3YuAppAR9FrEsPfUkuT-V4t0yOjCFAlS5Dqtn6It5la48EQDnL6XQ-YBzMaCACCkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gaia G against AEN for SDSS DR12 spectroscopically confirmed stars, galaxies, and quasars. The 321 lensed quasar images detected by Gaia are also overlaid as red dots. They are clearly separated from the galaxy locus.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476696/sty3366fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476696\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=QEdZH0ULO~mwRzIDSP5F8am-dBAkqGv~wquCQPMN-LGNO36XXO0iHwwXVRTcgWrPltmjt~FLxxS1~frxpqOvITWhbmpdgB31ZNTwGRLg6OvwmHl65iDg6yT~eiMrK3YKhblstb6DTteT2wSZ5C5j93292X8yBa2ahv2cWCAY4tfB29eF9nnVWdU6ZfVzgpFaQEJEIydVr4aEda-Kkj7gfpG50lQQVsOdByXk5RZvqI6yjTKdnHk2H9rDPxIkABRVKWBOH4zFtqRSpXEMby9errUhd3nwIm5PbCGSOuMwI-uWmAy2jDuV4vlk-oR3K4COL2bLjlX8Nwp8NbXDT75T3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476696&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia G</em> against AEN for SDSS DR12 spectroscopically confirmed stars, galaxies, and quasars. The 321 lensed quasar images detected by <em>Gaia</em> are also overlaid as red dots. They are clearly separated from the galaxy locus.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=yjqTR01bUXhqqNOBYTedxrGlbzSYoeVvxUaWAiDSvF7e96OABGAwZYx~aBDX1tDTSddNsxAGhuGFul1HJ7iEfbRlGsE5B~ikLUPRhprm8brpKDiOZqPhVF-gMFqj5XSDvWTMVx7gGNyUMQcj9unqI0DZXpecJua3~jdXWkPrCLpdhXoQBY0pCsfN-PdXpjCzI5jAGLRYrQ5k2-4nIxta6lhzMnX30Cn-mfE60xIvlZFqx8~rZVjaQSc1-44oyuEI3mSb3wM7Sl~FrOQYh30qG3YuAppAR9FrEsPfUkuT-V4t0yOjCFAlS5Dqtn6It5la48EQDnL6XQ-YBzMaCACCkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gaia G against AEN for SDSS DR12 spectroscopically confirmed stars, galaxies, and quasars. The 321 lensed quasar images detected by Gaia are also overlaid as red dots. They are clearly separated from the galaxy locus.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476696/sty3366fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476696\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=QEdZH0ULO~mwRzIDSP5F8am-dBAkqGv~wquCQPMN-LGNO36XXO0iHwwXVRTcgWrPltmjt~FLxxS1~frxpqOvITWhbmpdgB31ZNTwGRLg6OvwmHl65iDg6yT~eiMrK3YKhblstb6DTteT2wSZ5C5j93292X8yBa2ahv2cWCAY4tfB29eF9nnVWdU6ZfVzgpFaQEJEIydVr4aEda-Kkj7gfpG50lQQVsOdByXk5RZvqI6yjTKdnHk2H9rDPxIkABRVKWBOH4zFtqRSpXEMby9errUhd3nwIm5PbCGSOuMwI-uWmAy2jDuV4vlk-oR3K4COL2bLjlX8Nwp8NbXDT75T3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476696&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia G</em> against AEN for SDSS DR12 spectroscopically confirmed stars, galaxies, and quasars. The 321 lensed quasar images detected by <em>Gaia</em> are also overlaid as red dots. They are clearly separated from the galaxy locus.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The seven quasar images with AEN&gt;10 fall into three categories. PSJ0840+3550 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and WGD2038\u22124008 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>) have their large AEN image very close to a bright extended galaxy; WFI2026 (a 0.33 arcsec separation pair, Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and SDSSJ1640+1932 (a 0.72 arcsec separation pair, with both images catalogued by <em>Gaia</em>, Wang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) have very small separation image pairs; H1413+117 (Magain et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) and DESJ0405\u22123308 (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) are compact quads. The first two examples are likely to remain with a large AEN after subsequent <em>Gaia</em> data releases, though the remainder may improve as further scans at different angles are able to pin down each image. Surprisingly, the two detections in the Einstein cross, Q2237+030, have AENs of 2.2 and 3.0 in spite of all four images being embedded in the centre of the bulge of a relatively local (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 0.04) galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A search using an AEN cut based on separation would help recover the compact quad systems and still remove wider separation galaxy pairs. We however only use the AEN to prioritize candidates for most of our searches. Indeed, <em>Gaia</em> detections could be due to the lensing galaxy, for which a high AEN is expected (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.2.5</a> for such an example).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476699 id=\"129476699\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Removing crowded regions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">All-sky lens searches must perform a cut to remove very high-density regions on the sky. This is usually done by some cut on galactic latitude (e.g. Krone-Martins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) around |<em>b</em>| &gt; 15 or higher. While this effectively removes the galactic centre, it does not remove star clusters, extended star-forming regions, or the Magellanic clouds, and treats differently crowded areas of sky equally. <em>Gaia</em> by default allows us to remove regions where the concentration of contaminants (stars near quasars) becomes unmanageable. We do this following Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) by defining the local <em>Gaia</em> detection density per square degree within 100 arcsec of a particular target. A search-dependent cut is then placed on this density. For the Pan-STARRS footprint (\u223c30\u00a0832 deg<sup>2</sup>), after a density cut of 20\u00a0000 detections per square degree, the area drops to 22\u00a0094 (i.e. 72\u00a0per\u2009cent). For density cuts of 30\u00a0000, 50\u00a0000, and 100\u00a0000 detections per square degrees, the remaining areas are 24\u00a0336 (79\u00a0per\u2009cent), 26\u00a0939 (87\u00a0per\u2009cent), and 28\u00a0995 square degrees (94\u00a0per\u2009cent), respectively.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476701 id=\"129476701\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we present three searches for lensed quasars. For each search we use different cuts on number of <em>Gaia</em> detections, PMSIG, local <em>Gaia</em> density, and AEN.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476703 id=\"129476703\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections around quasar catalogues</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476704 id=\"129476704\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 WISE</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The Wide-Field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE, Wright et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) provided a full-sky survey at wavelengths of 3.4, 4.6, 12, and 22 microns (W1, W2, W3, and W4). This photometry has since been used as an efficient way to identify pure samples of quasars (e.g. DiPompeo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the ALLWISE detection rate of |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20 Milliquas quasars (Flesch <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1.2</a>) against Pan-STARRS <em>i</em>-band magnitude. The Pan-STARRS-to-ALLWISE crossmatch was made within 4 arcsec. At optical magnitudes less than 19.5 \u2013 roughly the faintest magnitude we expect for the sum of quasar images each detected by <em>Gaia</em>, and a lensing galaxy detected in Pan-STARRS \u2013 nearly all quasars are detected. Such a catalogue is ideal for searching for lensed quasars with multiple Gaia detections; however, we note that a small percentage of bright quasars are not detected due to blending with nearby bright galaxies or PSF spikes.</p>                        <a id=\"129476706\" scrollto-destination=\"129476706\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=JOU2AQOGgpbEz2rXnLoY1qySrmHYxsC7Xq5feSC9PM7SgBUkfbWrOxQJ3HwCOvfhuTAUtl1v68N2Kgg1GRzxOl5Ub3LlCX7PPzbnsTwrfMEXFFomlUbMVBSaU8S2nO4-~4-Sw2VfuhFKZ5L1QsmyOjfr4gzOYm5uclTeIlv~i9VoDQgBit-h9j1lq9-M15AgRx6M73O4BjQHDywERaJ0ntZF0j~e4KCQN-jvENiu~wERE5RF4Gt-Ytxf718s~zlmstArx6ycbBdXAU95ws0i0NHwtiCKjwqeeQ-~-IjeYoOsYENOuB9XgE9NJAD2hcC3mC9PRvSCf3uS-pRIu76aug__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ALLWISE catalogue detection rate of Milliquas quasars (|b| &gt; 20), as a function of Pan-STARRS iKRON magnitude. The lensed quasars with two or more Gaia detections (G &lt; 20.7) will have a total G-band (and approximately i-band) magnitude less than 19.9.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476706/sty3366fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476706\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=ZqUWsaA-RxMjWZ1SQWJFhhGN4s~MWnIST9Ue-jo~hno4V3D4dY5wyJIWMRgA3vpUv06lGx1UOMn5R~AaE5fccpOt2awtRYjcddkKXgv8VCSf9HTh5uY76sBBoaM1VNjvzJ1dOEaajqOsOAiyYmmmoAIPPi1dwV88ZLIne9GEVxoyXwWWUzZzU7BXc4wfpJdgQ990FTXxlbtSZUZ~oFvOMmO7GI7cIeayc1pcMB8NbV7Dwn6H-ypKPADP2E53Sxf7lzv34aFNPHKGi2Qux1x35n9MIcqw1b4A55jPv5j3njTLwfjOBCnuEZZ8CZon3BVlcvZTa~Q9SHVp5LNY8afheA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476706&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ALLWISE catalogue detection rate of Milliquas quasars (|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20), as a function of Pan-STARRS <em>i</em><sub>KRON</sub> magnitude. The lensed quasars with two or more Gaia detections (<em>G</em> &lt; 20.7) will have a total <em>G</em>-band (and approximately <em>i</em>-band) magnitude less than 19.9.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=JOU2AQOGgpbEz2rXnLoY1qySrmHYxsC7Xq5feSC9PM7SgBUkfbWrOxQJ3HwCOvfhuTAUtl1v68N2Kgg1GRzxOl5Ub3LlCX7PPzbnsTwrfMEXFFomlUbMVBSaU8S2nO4-~4-Sw2VfuhFKZ5L1QsmyOjfr4gzOYm5uclTeIlv~i9VoDQgBit-h9j1lq9-M15AgRx6M73O4BjQHDywERaJ0ntZF0j~e4KCQN-jvENiu~wERE5RF4Gt-Ytxf718s~zlmstArx6ycbBdXAU95ws0i0NHwtiCKjwqeeQ-~-IjeYoOsYENOuB9XgE9NJAD2hcC3mC9PRvSCf3uS-pRIu76aug__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ALLWISE catalogue detection rate of Milliquas quasars (|b| &gt; 20), as a function of Pan-STARRS iKRON magnitude. The lensed quasars with two or more Gaia detections (G &lt; 20.7) will have a total G-band (and approximately i-band) magnitude less than 19.9.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476706/sty3366fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476706\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=ZqUWsaA-RxMjWZ1SQWJFhhGN4s~MWnIST9Ue-jo~hno4V3D4dY5wyJIWMRgA3vpUv06lGx1UOMn5R~AaE5fccpOt2awtRYjcddkKXgv8VCSf9HTh5uY76sBBoaM1VNjvzJ1dOEaajqOsOAiyYmmmoAIPPi1dwV88ZLIne9GEVxoyXwWWUzZzU7BXc4wfpJdgQ990FTXxlbtSZUZ~oFvOMmO7GI7cIeayc1pcMB8NbV7Dwn6H-ypKPADP2E53Sxf7lzv34aFNPHKGi2Qux1x35n9MIcqw1b4A55jPv5j3njTLwfjOBCnuEZZ8CZon3BVlcvZTa~Q9SHVp5LNY8afheA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476706&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ALLWISE catalogue detection rate of Milliquas quasars (|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20), as a function of Pan-STARRS <em>i</em><sub>KRON</sub> magnitude. The lensed quasars with two or more Gaia detections (<em>G</em> &lt; 20.7) will have a total <em>G</em>-band (and approximately <em>i</em>-band) magnitude less than 19.9.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We repeat the search from Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) for multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections around red ALLWISE detections (Mainzer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). We visually inspect all sets of 2, 3, and 4 <em>Gaia</em> detections separated by less than 4.5 arcsec and all within 4.5 arcsec of an ALLWISE source satisfying W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2, 0.3, and 0.4, respectively, and W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a015.5. Constraints on PMSIG and local stellar density are varied for each selection and summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. These cuts are as loose as possible while still keeping the number of systems inspected manageable.</p>                        <a id=\"129476708\" scrollto-destination=\"129476708\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of lens selection techniques. For each method, the number of required <em>Gaia</em> detections, density cut and PMSIG cut is given. All searches also include a <em>Gaia</em> magnitude threshold of <em>G</em> &gt; 15. We note the candidates are not mutually exclusive.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quasar selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>Gaia</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Density<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PMSIG<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>N<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.2\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>&lt;100\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;18\u00a0</td><td>2895\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>&lt;50\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;15\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0274\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.4\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;30\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;10\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0397\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>unWISE model\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Milliquas\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0046\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spec. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1/2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0201/3056\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Morph. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;5\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0156\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quasar selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>Gaia</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Density<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PMSIG<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>N<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.2\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>&lt;100\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;18\u00a0</td><td>2895\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>&lt;50\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;15\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0274\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.4\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;30\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;10\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0397\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>unWISE model\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Milliquas\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0046\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spec. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1/2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0201/3056\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Morph. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;5\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0156\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476708\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of lens selection techniques. For each method, the number of required <em>Gaia</em> detections, density cut and PMSIG cut is given. All searches also include a <em>Gaia</em> magnitude threshold of <em>G</em> &gt; 15. We note the candidates are not mutually exclusive.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quasar selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>Gaia</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Density<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PMSIG<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>N<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.2\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>&lt;100\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;18\u00a0</td><td>2895\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>&lt;50\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;15\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0274\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.4\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;30\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;10\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0397\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>unWISE model\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Milliquas\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0046\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spec. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1/2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0201/3056\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Morph. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;5\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0156\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Quasar selection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>N</em><sub>Gaia</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Density<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>PMSIG<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>N<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.2\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td>&lt;100\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;18\u00a0</td><td>2895\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.3\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>&lt;50\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;15\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0274\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>W1\u2212W2 &gt;0.4\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;30\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;10\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0397\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>unWISE model\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Milliquas\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>14\u00a0046\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spec. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1/2\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;12\u00a0</td><td>11\u00a0201/3056\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Morph. Gals\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td>&lt;20\u00a0000\u00a0</td><td>&lt;5\u00a0</td><td>22\u00a0156\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476708\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476709 id=\"129476709\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 Milliquas</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The quasar catalogue from Flesch (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) contains nearly 2 million high-confidence quasars.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> While this catalogue has a large overlap with the WISE colour-selected sample, it includes quasars detected in the X-ray and radio. At these wavelengths a lensed quasar with a bright lensing galaxy will still be selected, whereas in optical- and infrared-selected catalogues, the galaxy can shift the system away from the quasar locus and hence remove it from the selection. For this catalogue we require two <em>Gaia</em> detections both within 4.5 arcsec of the catalogue position and separated from each other by less than 4.5 arcsec. This yields 14\u00a0046 candidates along with a density cut of 20\u00a0000 and PMSIG less than 12.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476711 id=\"129476711\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Modelling unWISE pixels</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The FWHM of the WISE PSF in the W1 and W2 bands is \u223c 6 arcsec. While a quasar and star separated by a few arcseconds will be blended and catalogued as one object, the WISE pixels can be modelled if the PSF and positions of the components are known, as has been demonstrated with SDSS data (Lang, Hogg\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) using a set of unblurred WISE coadds (unWISE, Lang <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We apply this technique, using the <em>Gaia</em> positions and ALLWISE catalogue positions, to the most up-to-date unWISE coadds and PSFs (Meisner, Lang\u00a0&amp; Schlegel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The data are very well calibrated astrometrically, allowing us to use the <em>Gaia</em> positions to model the pixels directly without needing to infer a registration between the two data sets. Any modelled cutouts must be large enough to include PSF spikes from nearby stars, but also small enough for the relative component fit to be computationally fast. Therefore, we divide the sky through an equal area HealPix tiling (G\u00f3rski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), resulting in 50\u00a0331\u00a0648 70 x 70 arcsec tiles across the whole sky. Each tile overlaps neighbouring tiles by 5 arcsec in order to ensure that lens candidates at the edges of these tiles are not missed. Applying the following process to each of these cutouts resulted in 25\u00a0129 candidates. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>Gaia</em> density (as defined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>) is calculated at the tile centre, and the modelling proceeds if this is below 20\u00a0000 per square degree.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">If any close pair of <em>Gaia</em> detections exists on the cutout separated by 5 arcsec and any PMSIG values are less than 10, the modelling proceeds.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">For both the W1 and W2 bands, a model is built by placing unWISE PSFs at the positions of all <em>Gaia</em> detections, and at ALLWISE catalogue detections which are more than 2 arcsec from a <em>Gaia</em> detection. A uniform background is added to this model.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fluxes of each PSF and background level are inferred through a non-negative least squares fit to the data weighted by the uncertainty maps. These are then converted into best-fitting W1 and W2 Vega magnitudes.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">If for each component of the close pairs, W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a015.5 and either W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.4 or G\u2212W1\u00a0&gt;\u00a03.75, a Pan-STARRS cutout is visually inspected. See Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> for these colour cuts.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test this technique\u2019s efficiency at recovering known lenses, we extracted W1 and W2 magnitudes for all 147 known lensed quasars with two or more <em>Gaia</em> detections. The <em>Gaia G</em>, W1, W2 colour plot for the reddest two components of all 147 systems is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> (without cuts on separation or PMSIG). From the list of previously followed-up systems (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), we compiled a list of 127 spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star systems that were identified as potential lensed quasar systems in previous lens searches (Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). 52 of these systems have two <em>Gaia</em> detections. We plot their modelled WISE\u00a0+\u00a0<em>Gaia</em> colours in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, separating the stellar and quasar components.</p>                        <a id=\"129476714\" scrollto-destination=\"129476714\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=YeLGVeqjIhahSlwrYVFqMHHofK5GHvCVdCC~V9Itym0~7kRInnYMSDThiIiz5aLQ5Ffozb4S5Y54vjLtIMX3lqi0URkLPT5sRj~I~YL-cV-5K6MZlL0LOveOaQrur~Au45GmdEicapaclw9LkU0VIBEQCKi3Ix2XGveDHctLpnpETNYz2hW1FFKMbiElJADX19MtZ5ds1ls-EWdm-h-Wgk6JYeUi1rTFoXgECvXOHz5WeNcxvH4nY1lecxCmpkbnr~SjxybcWqVVqJVVPT6hkRgdoEM-wwv9NRNx8ae41c3SXCNmqEid7tOGA8F8jNt5rLVLbd~eNgJqXBs-MwYf2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gaia\u2013WISE colour plots. When more than two images are present, the two with the reddest W1\u2212W2 points are plotted. The red circles show the less red component of this pair, i.e. W1\u2013W2(A) &gt; W1\u2013W2(B). Right: Modelled unWISE W1, W2 and Gaia G colours for 52 spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star contaminant systems. The stellar components\u2019 colours are plotted as red circles. A cut of W1\u2212W2\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.4 and G \u2212W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.75 removed 41/52 contaminant systems, while keeping 145/147 lensed quasars.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476714/sty3366fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476714\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=LHrBS1ocfuPFmMbkrx5g5cG7ktUr0LiyWiyePIlqrKlQDooxJ8TYPNjk6CFg49L3BNqq9YBTzVHL-VIvqbFNEqsQqm1tEV6AmVg8krVirkkIfSWWVW2JM97QEJRL3fblk9KZerQRsokuOroozTAo8MYBIzkAV9ROG~AK87~WcFB-CGumpTY3db81tfskhAaktBoHlhrmPfD8B5mJDuVy3npJcFpsU9Q4o7bf1vBJ3eQJnQf3WRbjf4~1yoK9sLgvgNOEDqaIf8Ut~QkfnCv01vN26PqKAM8mEdH2ZI6QebKmV2kxJgzE3RgRpxHOZYh3498cd2Xeaf3z~0KqQ4qQwA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476714&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em>\u2013WISE colour plots. <em>Left</em>: modelled unWISE W1, W2 and <em>Gaia G</em> colours for all 147 known lensed quasars with two or more <em>Gaia</em> detections. When more than two images are present, the two with the reddest W1\u2212W2 points are plotted. The red circles show the less red component of this pair, i.e. W1\u2013W2(A) &gt; W1\u2013W2(B). <em>Right</em>: Modelled unWISE W1, W2 and <em>Gaia G</em> colours for 52 spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star contaminant systems. The stellar components\u2019 colours are plotted as red circles. A cut of W1\u2212W2\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.4 and <em>G</em> \u2212W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.75 removed 41/52 contaminant systems, while keeping 145/147 lensed quasars.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=YeLGVeqjIhahSlwrYVFqMHHofK5GHvCVdCC~V9Itym0~7kRInnYMSDThiIiz5aLQ5Ffozb4S5Y54vjLtIMX3lqi0URkLPT5sRj~I~YL-cV-5K6MZlL0LOveOaQrur~Au45GmdEicapaclw9LkU0VIBEQCKi3Ix2XGveDHctLpnpETNYz2hW1FFKMbiElJADX19MtZ5ds1ls-EWdm-h-Wgk6JYeUi1rTFoXgECvXOHz5WeNcxvH4nY1lecxCmpkbnr~SjxybcWqVVqJVVPT6hkRgdoEM-wwv9NRNx8ae41c3SXCNmqEid7tOGA8F8jNt5rLVLbd~eNgJqXBs-MwYf2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gaia\u2013WISE colour plots. Left: modelled unWISE W1, W2 and Gaia G colours for all 147 known lensed quasars with two or more Gaia detections. When more than two images are present, the two with the reddest W1\u2212W2 points are plotted. The red circles show the less red component of this pair, i.e. W1\u2013W2(A) &gt; W1\u2013W2(B). Right: Modelled unWISE W1, W2 and Gaia G colours for 52 spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star contaminant systems. The stellar components\u2019 colours are plotted as red circles. A cut of W1\u2212W2\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.4 and G \u2212W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.75 removed 41/52 contaminant systems, while keeping 145/147 lensed quasars.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476714/sty3366fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476714\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=LHrBS1ocfuPFmMbkrx5g5cG7ktUr0LiyWiyePIlqrKlQDooxJ8TYPNjk6CFg49L3BNqq9YBTzVHL-VIvqbFNEqsQqm1tEV6AmVg8krVirkkIfSWWVW2JM97QEJRL3fblk9KZerQRsokuOroozTAo8MYBIzkAV9ROG~AK87~WcFB-CGumpTY3db81tfskhAaktBoHlhrmPfD8B5mJDuVy3npJcFpsU9Q4o7bf1vBJ3eQJnQf3WRbjf4~1yoK9sLgvgNOEDqaIf8Ut~QkfnCv01vN26PqKAM8mEdH2ZI6QebKmV2kxJgzE3RgRpxHOZYh3498cd2Xeaf3z~0KqQ4qQwA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476714&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Gaia</em>\u2013WISE colour plots. <em>Left</em>: modelled unWISE W1, W2 and <em>Gaia G</em> colours for all 147 known lensed quasars with two or more <em>Gaia</em> detections. When more than two images are present, the two with the reddest W1\u2212W2 points are plotted. The red circles show the less red component of this pair, i.e. W1\u2013W2(A) &gt; W1\u2013W2(B). <em>Right</em>: Modelled unWISE W1, W2 and <em>Gaia G</em> colours for 52 spectroscopically confirmed quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star contaminant systems. The stellar components\u2019 colours are plotted as red circles. A cut of W1\u2212W2\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.4 and <em>G</em> \u2212W1\u00a0&lt;\u00a03.75 removed 41/52 contaminant systems, while keeping 145/147 lensed quasars.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Only two lens systems have a component with no modelled W1 or W2 flux, both with <em>Gaia</em> detections separated by less than 1 arcsec: SDSSJ1640+1932 (Wang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and SDSSJ0248+1913 (Ostrovksi et\u00a0al. in preparation, Delchambre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, 21 such examples exist in the quasar\u00a0+\u00a0star sample. Using the previously mentioned colour cuts, we are able to remove 41 of the 52 contaminants, while keeping 145 of the 147 lensed quasars. The contaminant systems are already biased to those systems which most resemble lensed quasars, as the search teams thought they merit spectroscopic follow-up. The 11 contaminant systems which evade our colour cut removal are all 1 arcsec or less separation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">On application, about 1 in 20 tiles from steps (i) and (ii) are subject to unWISE model fitting, while approximately 1 in 300 of these contain systems passing the remaining colour criteria. The main contaminants are galaxy pairs and pairs of <em>Gaia</em> sources on bright WISE star streaks. Since there is no required cut on the W1\u2212W2 colour of each component, any source for which <em>Gaia</em> is not capturing all the flux \u2013 for example, PSFs with nearby galaxies \u2013 will lead to an inflated G\u2212W1 colour, bringing the system into our inspected sample. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows that our selection efficiency can be improved by applying a strict cut of W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00, without any change to the completeness.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476717 id=\"129476717\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 LRGs with <em>Gaia</em> detections</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Quasar-colour-selected lensed quasar searches will be biased away from discovering systems with bright lensing galaxies (see Lucey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We therefore aim to complement our quasar-colour-selected search with a search for <em>Gaia</em> detections around bright galaxies. First, we use the SDSS DR12 spectroscopic galaxy sample (i.e. any spectra with CLASS \u00a0=\u00a0\u2018GALAXY\u2019). For each galaxy, we require two detections separated by less than 4.5 arcsec, and each within 4.5 arcsec of the SDSS position. A second search is also performed requiring just one <em>Gaia</em> detection between 1 and 3.5 arcsec from the galaxy. After a cut on the PMSIG of 8 and AEN of 5, the two searches yielded 3056 and 11\u00a0201 candidates, respectively.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Thirdly, we perform a search for bright morphological Pan-STARRS galaxies satisfying <em>i</em><sub>PSF</sub> \u2212 <em>i</em><sub>KRON</sub> &gt; 0.7, <em>i</em><sub>KRON</sub> &lt; 19, and with at least one <em>Gaia</em> detection between 1 and 3 arcsec away. We apply further cuts of PMSIG &lt; 5 and an AEN &lt; 5 on the nearest <em>Gaia</em> detection, yielding 22\u00a0156 candidates. These search criteria recover previous lenses with bright lensing galaxies and only one <em>Gaia</em> detection, i.e. SDSSJ0819+5356 (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), PSJ0123\u22120455, and PSJ1602+4526 (Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476720 id=\"129476720\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Final candidate selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The total number of candidates selected by each technique is shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. For each candidate, a Pan-STARRS <em>gri</em> colour image is inspected. The majority of candidates are discarded since they are obvious contaminants \u2013 they have components with different colours, or the <em>Gaia</em> detections correspond to extended galaxies. The most promising candidates, showing nearby PSFs of similar colours, are graded between 1 and 10. The most promising quad candidates with similar unWISE model colours are given a grade of 10. Doubles showing putative lensing galaxies are graded 7\u20139 depending on component colours, proper motion values, and AEN value, while pairs without lensing galaxies were graded 1\u20136 depending on the same information.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For any WISE-selected candidates, the W1 and W2 images are checked for contamination from nearby stars/galaxies. Finally, the model <em>G</em>\u2013W1 and W1\u2013W2 colours are inspected for all remaining candidates, and their grades adjusted according to their relative position to the quasar locus (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The candidates with the highest grades are prioritized for follow-up.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476723 id=\"129476723\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectra of 33 candidates were taken on 2018 July 11 and 2018 July 12 using ISIS on the William Herschel Telescope in variable seeing and cloud cover conditions. The R158R and R300B gratings were used on the red and blue arms, respectively, along with the standard 5300 \u00c5 dichroic and GG495 second-order cut filter in the red arm. This provided a dispersion of 1.81 \u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> and 0.86\u2009\u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> for the red and blue arms, respectively. The component spectra were extracted using a <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span>-based pipeline which accounts for the CCD response and trace variation based on the standard star Hz 44. The final spectra, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, were extracted using a Gaussian aperture of varying width centred on each component. The 2D spectra were also visually inspected to confirm that the spectral features were spatially resolved. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> provides a summary of all WHT observations, including the <em>Gaia</em> magnitudes, colour information, and proper motions. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows colour images of all observed systems, with <em>Gaia</em> DR2 detections overlaid.</p>                        <a id=\"129476725\" scrollto-destination=\"129476725\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=LaZmIenXaRY6DIs0j2Tjl4NF4N~NNzmZnzeh8BFOWiTmLRexYsBRjiny2Fp2c98WFuO3KRIJRvWc1zUmxMbabM3lNYoXNACiC-M9SDZsfykpuLxKnQ5mYggCK2Q7w-OZwMmNTT6P~htsDf3wE~NSrXZp3ACcLr-v3g3VqR3wgTdV6I-erATMXyB0mCGR8A~zAUkm7ubaEE7k-jEVQggEgqVc3xOI8MiehyFTxTE1e-z3ih19qTNmZFkr0Rlw-ZMCVct9O8fBcNgW8WSsFd~ZrBgHV57R370XwOC6ino8vhLwgyer3uBLN6jXxyXG3RULv7GIyndVo5rqaCIutbXp4w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spectra of all observed candidates. Cutouts are 10 x 10 arcsec in size.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=J3sGONtHKXMyEsGP9jtJuNkMu18F~JMWjV2RMZyDCNP0WKOsvDCRrm9qbzpMjqv5eHV9Lp59b~QaBNqvbIqhqYSsCkUiHWEldY~eqaH8oEoV4FhLV1tQI1eRTbFuzEn1RIlTTaRk5Hz76cKHRN2JrC0pg7w1Ehr2CpT8ncH-StUmGDREwQRs7VENWARSteo0lnbnO7MEHzp~L0~DVvFE1FW3JlCGR1fjH64GBgcwdpXFX1BpiNTsGsByc2vyMZ7ZwCvrka5Pvt4GBNGGCjyIyMUqZ4tg4p~8thCIVN3uhz3-5BU3BLoNBicCWqVWbgcY5c0lCTJbku~IFhkpKZG2uw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS gri colour images of all observed candidates, except for J1537\u22123010 which is archival DECam grz and J2350+3654 is HSC gi. Gaia</em> detections are overlaid as blue crosses. Cutouts are 10 x 10 arcsec in size.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"129476727\" scrollto-destination=\"129476727\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observations. NIQ = nearly identical quasar, assigned to systems of quasars at the same redshift but without photometric detection of a lensing galaxy. href=\"/view-large/129476727\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476728 id=\"129476728\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Modelling</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>grizY</em> Pan-STARRS images are modelled as in Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). For each observed system, a Moffat profile is fit to a nearby star to determine the PSF. All quasar images are fit with PSFs, and galaxies with Sersic profiles convolved with the PSF. The positions and galaxy parameters are inferred using <em>emcee</em> (Foreman-Mackey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), while allowing for an astrometric offset between each band. When the nearby star\u2019s Moffat profile is not a good fit for the lens system\u2019s PSF, the Moffat parameters are inferred simultaneously with the astrometry. The astrometry and photometry for all systems are provided in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#app1\">A</a>. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> shows <em>gri</em> colour images of each system, with galaxy and PSF positions overlaid, alongside model galaxy-subtracted and model PSF-subtracted <em>gri</em> images.</p>                        <a id=\"129476730\" scrollto-destination=\"129476730\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=NuwsY9nwEjRgn9Q8OIEXuBYE0whEnKL5TSqViwna5p6e4eOlErZQkD8XrO4uD~CUaBh8YrL2czZbPeSMK1P-0jXo-Lx1KxOuvzqveUuS06emBicS~A4-JJ0gZSfJsHi2Gjg-AwMgZszkIISPc3q8yXzwwy~GwYULIcbw8XuluRDVwLhsZsMRMIeTxYetatlAqwV6n1sZN-JUMM8endHbZZ~b0Mpn5hHtXLxCMqhz3plm18KpsZoue9-eh0R9qRfNvbngQaFyt3CJdYQfur3fuGNs31kQ5jRW82OMe1nPc~NUFefFOAmIxxWuWrlRhHS7ix1y2VNx64haxPxzeU24aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS modelled pixels. Left: gri colour image; middle: model galaxy subtracted; right: model quasar PSFs subtracted. PSF and galaxy positions are overlaid with blue and red crosses, respectively. In the case of J1653+5155, the MzLS+BASS DR6 grz pixels are used. For J1238+2846 and J1616+1415, the colour images are grz and izY to show the lensing galaxy more clearly.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476730/sty3366fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476730\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=3c4MKMpfvYuBt6TgxZTU0nyfO~YK3WjqJ8NOYH-NWR78ErBCq-Et2sgnbxbgogp--XzdcRd6yV0VfihmzGE7VOTExAmd8pwUri-E9v-jNfSo-GMdBj6XWhf3DTI9D0GCEO1doqjGeB176Pl3Txhn6FD-1m29gXbYI14x7c26nGaClqE7KfWGFYMcjO8~SKrxQP5NlYnyDcS4oct~gIG~IFAx4Hzweg3uVTr131ZhcZ3S6WGPdpnqfWX~ChAHmCOeoVE7l1uwboOnmLs63lJFnRjZTnIwetH1~pSbMH3cjxpg1tVBLVrUWRxBEPCWJ409NQbGp7R3uaVlR~8sQFwjag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476730&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pan-STARRS modelled pixels. <em>Left: gri</em> colour image; <em>middle:</em> model galaxy subtracted; <em>right:</em> model quasar PSFs subtracted. PSF and galaxy positions are overlaid with blue and red crosses, respectively. In the case of J1653+5155, the MzLS+BASS DR6 <em>grz</em> pixels are used. For J1238+2846 and J1616+1415, the colour images are <em>grz</em> and <em>izY</em> to show the lensing galaxy more clearly.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=NuwsY9nwEjRgn9Q8OIEXuBYE0whEnKL5TSqViwna5p6e4eOlErZQkD8XrO4uD~CUaBh8YrL2czZbPeSMK1P-0jXo-Lx1KxOuvzqveUuS06emBicS~A4-JJ0gZSfJsHi2Gjg-AwMgZszkIISPc3q8yXzwwy~GwYULIcbw8XuluRDVwLhsZsMRMIeTxYetatlAqwV6n1sZN-JUMM8endHbZZ~b0Mpn5hHtXLxCMqhz3plm18KpsZoue9-eh0R9qRfNvbngQaFyt3CJdYQfur3fuGNs31kQ5jRW82OMe1nPc~NUFefFOAmIxxWuWrlRhHS7ix1y2VNx64haxPxzeU24aQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Pan-STARRS modelled pixels. Left: gri colour image; middle: model galaxy subtracted; right: model quasar PSFs subtracted. PSF and galaxy positions are overlaid with blue and red crosses, respectively. In the case of J1653+5155, the MzLS+BASS DR6 grz pixels are used. For J1238+2846 and J1616+1415, the colour images are grz and izY to show the lensing galaxy more clearly.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476730/sty3366fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476730\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=3c4MKMpfvYuBt6TgxZTU0nyfO~YK3WjqJ8NOYH-NWR78ErBCq-Et2sgnbxbgogp--XzdcRd6yV0VfihmzGE7VOTExAmd8pwUri-E9v-jNfSo-GMdBj6XWhf3DTI9D0GCEO1doqjGeB176Pl3Txhn6FD-1m29gXbYI14x7c26nGaClqE7KfWGFYMcjO8~SKrxQP5NlYnyDcS4oct~gIG~IFAx4Hzweg3uVTr131ZhcZ3S6WGPdpnqfWX~ChAHmCOeoVE7l1uwboOnmLs63lJFnRjZTnIwetH1~pSbMH3cjxpg1tVBLVrUWRxBEPCWJ409NQbGp7R3uaVlR~8sQFwjag__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476730&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pan-STARRS modelled pixels. <em>Left: gri</em> colour image; <em>middle:</em> model galaxy subtracted; <em>right:</em> model quasar PSFs subtracted. PSF and galaxy positions are overlaid with blue and red crosses, respectively. In the case of J1653+5155, the MzLS+BASS DR6 <em>grz</em> pixels are used. For J1238+2846 and J1616+1415, the colour images are <em>grz</em> and <em>izY</em> to show the lensing galaxy more clearly.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each lens we constrain a singular isothermal ellipsoid (SIE) mass model using the inferred galaxy and image positions and their uncertainties. These positions provide six constraints for doubles and 10 for quads (excepting J2145+6345, for which no lensing galaxy is detected in the Pan-STARRS data). The model requires a source position, galaxy mass position, and SIE Einstein radius, axial ratio, and position angle, i.e. seven parameters. We also use the median flux ratios in the <em>griz</em> bands, with a 20\u00a0per\u2009cent uncertainty included to mitigate against microlensing or variations arising from the different light paths. For the quads, flux ratios are also used as constraints, with the uncertainty set at 50\u00a0per\u2009cent for saddle points, since microlensing is more likely to suppress them (Schechter\u00a0&amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). An external shear is included for the quad mass models. We expect \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 0 for the double systems, and \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 4 for the quads (\u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c 2 for J2145+6345). The best-fitting mass model parameters, galaxy light flattenings, and lens model magnifications are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> . The \u03c7<sup>2</sup> contributions from the image positions, lens mass-light misalignment, and flux ratios are also given for each system\u2019s best-fitting model. Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows a summary of the confirmed lensed quasars.</p>                        <a id=\"129476732\" scrollto-destination=\"129476732\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div
