         \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/129476733\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=129476734 id=\"129476734\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Notes on individual systems</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476735 id=\"129476735\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-1>5.2.1 J0203+1612</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was selected as a single <em>Gaia</em> detection near a spectroscopic galaxy. The 1\u00a0h BOSS spectrum reveals a LRG spectrum at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 0.488 with obvious quasar emission lines (Dawson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> shows the original BOSS spectrum, best-fitting galaxy model spectrum, and the residuals. Four quasar emission lines have been identified at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 2.18, with potential broad absorption blueward of the C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line. We targetted J0203+1612 with the WHT for 1200\u00a0s however the spectrum (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) reveals no broad lines, perhaps due to high airmass observations coupled with variable weather conditions. Given the definite presence of a low-redshift galaxy and a high-redshift quasar within the BOSS 2 arcsec fibre diameter, as well as the imaging showing two point sources either side of the massive galaxy, it is a strong lens candidate. To test this we compare the stellar mass from a composite stellar population synthesis model based on the galaxy\u2019s colours and redshift with the lensing mass within the Einstein radius under the assumption of strong gravitational lensing. For the former we used the median colours derived from the pixel modelling (Appendix A), along with the galaxy\u2019s spectroscopic redshift. Using the Bayesian stellar population analysis code of Auger et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we derive a <em>total</em> stellar mass of log<sub>10</sub>(M/M<sub>\u2299</sub>)\u00a0= 11.66\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05 (11.42\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05) for a Salpeter (Chabrier) IMF. In contrast our SIE lens model implies the Einstein mass within the Einstein radius is log<sub>10</sub>(M/M<sub>\u2299</sub>) \u224811.64. This lensing mass to stellar mass ratio is typical for samples of strong lenses (e.g. Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and is on the more conservative side of the gravitational lensing regime since the predicted Einstein radius from the stellar mass is marginally larger than the mass model predicts. On balance, we expect that this is a gravitationally lensed quasar.</p>                        <a id=\"129476737\" scrollto-destination=\"129476737\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=VI-HQMciOaw7uVeFet5UuBFjC6BcGTYFhuceM3a377qOU87VyXQbZgW5dP5QZ64YQNfcl2WNjz~t~b9BdD53wyMgy3KRHjnVwYnHqtoUVJM0SoXdh8H4PijsyCcMObVQD9HrEkDKO0uQ7st7e9APpqZKVy47KYOaMoEku3yjq31J3WRasWNwKcdwe4FSue-thS2fmFE7Us1pnu-XDhazpUn3A9EyDhiJLDkLBHp~G7NrEXg9W~aWu~zkvfrRQdG53ooNqIV8ctViDU5YhyWB~Hoc4siTmLluS41pFbqx0KCjWmI~P3ASf6jqqOzG5SjAK-BzDOiEfhbGILr-Sf3m-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: BOSS spectrum of J0203+1612, classified as a galaxy with pipeline galaxy model overlaid; Bottom: galaxy model subtracted from the data (residual signal-to-noise) clearly showing several quasar emission lines at $z$\u00a0= 2.18.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476737/sty3366fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476737\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=Lw8lNxyPFjZpOuo75Dog7RJ7VBfwMjYI88pL2yfekV-rYMRCRmThU2VoF97yVWO3ErM8h1tVtLdCXrKgSev6z0TrNHkgU9bfCOBPuJ888dgi1Vk9kauMB4L~ZigftW50~CFLQkSpub4LwWU0v7BQI7eBKaH4eFGBsaOVmK-BBmTdJHgqeWoRe8exiqX-uLeyVWT082S1gNkB27pEuU1Pys~VLM8qQDVRSgiRlTRVe2j1adQ0wVHS4XadtxWX7Ki11XuzI5F3TMsCfG-qaulfVIGSB4IxKYB41sGU6PKk7vB8djiDLDtfoJgKPASWuojzp~cb08FbkeChSfEzyGJt1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476737&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Top</em>: BOSS spectrum of J0203+1612, classified as a galaxy with pipeline galaxy model overlaid; <em>Bottom</em>: galaxy model subtracted from the data (residual signal-to-noise) clearly showing several quasar emission lines at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 2.18.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=VI-HQMciOaw7uVeFet5UuBFjC6BcGTYFhuceM3a377qOU87VyXQbZgW5dP5QZ64YQNfcl2WNjz~t~b9BdD53wyMgy3KRHjnVwYnHqtoUVJM0SoXdh8H4PijsyCcMObVQD9HrEkDKO0uQ7st7e9APpqZKVy47KYOaMoEku3yjq31J3WRasWNwKcdwe4FSue-thS2fmFE7Us1pnu-XDhazpUn3A9EyDhiJLDkLBHp~G7NrEXg9W~aWu~zkvfrRQdG53ooNqIV8ctViDU5YhyWB~Hoc4siTmLluS41pFbqx0KCjWmI~P3ASf6jqqOzG5SjAK-BzDOiEfhbGILr-Sf3m-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: BOSS spectrum of J0203+1612, classified as a galaxy with pipeline galaxy model overlaid; Bottom: galaxy model subtracted from the data (residual signal-to-noise) clearly showing several quasar emission lines at $z$\u00a0= 2.18.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476737/sty3366fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476737\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=Lw8lNxyPFjZpOuo75Dog7RJ7VBfwMjYI88pL2yfekV-rYMRCRmThU2VoF97yVWO3ErM8h1tVtLdCXrKgSev6z0TrNHkgU9bfCOBPuJ888dgi1Vk9kauMB4L~ZigftW50~CFLQkSpub4LwWU0v7BQI7eBKaH4eFGBsaOVmK-BBmTdJHgqeWoRe8exiqX-uLeyVWT082S1gNkB27pEuU1Pys~VLM8qQDVRSgiRlTRVe2j1adQ0wVHS4XadtxWX7Ki11XuzI5F3TMsCfG-qaulfVIGSB4IxKYB41sGU6PKk7vB8djiDLDtfoJgKPASWuojzp~cb08FbkeChSfEzyGJt1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476737&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Top</em>: BOSS spectrum of J0203+1612, classified as a galaxy with pipeline galaxy model overlaid; <em>Bottom</em>: galaxy model subtracted from the data (residual signal-to-noise) clearly showing several quasar emission lines at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0= 2.18.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476738 id=\"129476738\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-2>5.2.2 J1238+2846</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The WHT spectra show a shared broad emission line at 6410 \u00c5 (and perhaps a line at 5210 \u00c5) for each component of this pair. The southern component has a BOSS spectrum clearly revealing much higher signal-to-noise versions of these emission lines, corresponding to C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, respectively. Interestingly the BOSS spectrum also shows strong Ly\u03b1 and NV which are not present in our WHT spectrum. This is probably due to the candidate being targetted at the very start of the night at high airmass and with the slit aligned along the two images rather than the parallactic angle, reducing the amount of flux to the blue arm. The lensing galaxy is revealed most readily in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> band and is verified in both the Pan-STARRS and DECaLS <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>-band data.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476740 id=\"129476740\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-3>5.2.3 J1307+0642</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was selected using <em>Chandra</em> archival observations and <em>Gaia</em> (Lemon et\u00a0al. in preparation). The <em>Chandra</em> data resolve two X-ray point sources coinciding with two optically blue point sources either side of a bright galaxy (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). The optical spectrum shows hints of an emission line around 4700 \u00c5. An SDSS spectrum reveals the lensing galaxy to be at <em>z</em> \u00a0=\u00a00.23. However, no quasar emission lines are seen upon subtraction of the model spectrum. A deeper spectrum is required to determine the source redshift for this object.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476742 id=\"129476742\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-4>5.2.4 J1418\u22121610</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The blue arm reveals no broad emission lines, however as in the case of J1238+2846, it was observed at high airmass. The red arm reveals two prominent emission line at \u223c5960 and \u223c9260 \u00c5, suggesting Mg\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and H\u03b3 at <em>z</em> \u00a0=\u00a01.13. This is in agreement with the subsequent identification of H\u03b4 and FeII (\u223c3200 \u00c5) in the stacked spectrum, and also with a UV excess as detected by <em>GALEX</em>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476744 id=\"129476744\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-5>5.2.5 J1524+4801</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This doubly imaged lens was selected both by the unWISE modelling and the W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.4 double <em>Gaia</em> detection search. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows that the two <em>Gaia</em> detections correspond to a quasar image (<em>G</em> = 20.29, AEN \u00a0=\u00a01.98), and the lensing galaxy (<em>G</em> = 20.60, AEN \u00a0=\u00a017.53). Surprisingly the lens galaxy is fainter (<em>i</em> \u00a0=\u00a019.56) than most other galaxies with <em>Gaia</em> detections, suggesting a compact central region. This lens is the first known lensed quasar for which <em>Gaia</em> has catalogued the lensing galaxy, opening up new search opportunities. Our searches have revealed other candidates with apparent lensing galaxies detected by <em>Gaia</em>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476746 id=\"129476746\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-6>5.2.6 J1537\u22123010</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our WHT spectra reveal that the eastern and southern images share a broad emission line at 4212 \u00c5. A second emission line at 5190 \u00c5 has been identified with Subaru (Rusu, private communication). This places the source at a redshift of <em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span></em>\u00a0= 1.72, with the two lines being C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>, respectively. The SIE\u00a0+\u00a0shear mass model provides a good fit, \u03c7<sup>2</sup> \u223c5 given four degrees of freedom. The majority of this derives from image B being half as bright as the model predicts. The shear has a magnitude of 0.07, 34 deg east of north. This candidate was also independently selected by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) as GRAL153725327\u2212301017053 and spectroscopically confirmed (Delchambre et\u00a0al., private communication).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476748 id=\"129476748\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-7>5.2.7 J1817+2729</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This object was selected by the W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2, 4 <em>Gaia</em> detections search. One of these detections is due to a very nearby star. Given its high stellar density and apparent lack of a lensing galaxy or fourth image, it was given a low follow-up priority. However, we upgraded the priority given its selection by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) as GRAL181730853+272940139, as in the case of J2014\u22123024. Resolved spectra verify images A, C, and D are at a redshift of <em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span></em>\u00a0= 3.07. Our SIE\u00a0+\u00a0shear model predicts a highly flattened mass distribution with <em>q</em>\u00a0= 0.21 orientated 54 deg east of north, and a strong shear of 0.27, \u221234 deg east of north. The light from the galaxy is also highly elongated, <em>q</em>\u00a0= 0.1, and in a remarkably similar direction to the mass (56 deg east of north). The main contribution to \u03c7<sup>2</sup> is the flux ratio, with image B being four\u00a0times fainter than predicted by our SIE\u00a0+\u00a0shear model. This is a saddle point and such images can be strongly demagnified by microlensing (Schechter\u00a0&amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). We note that such a strong shear, orthogonal to the mass distribution likely suggests a limitation in the choice of lensing model. Rusu\u00a0&amp; Lemon (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) discuss a more intricate mass model, based on deeper Subaru imaging, and suggest that the lensing galaxy is an edge-on disc. The lensing nature has been independently spectroscopically confirmed by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (private communication).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476750 id=\"129476750\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-8>5.2.8 J1949+7732</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens is an XMM source (Pineau et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and has a source redshift of <em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span></em>\u00a0= 1.63. The SDSS data show that the north-eastern component is brightest in all bands, while the Pan-STARRS data clearly show the opposite. The <em>Gaia</em> magnitudes corroborate the Pan-STARRS flux ratios (<em>G</em> \u00a0=\u00a018.71, 19.51 for A and B). Similar to J0235\u22122433, it has both images detected by <em>Gaia</em>, and so a light curve will help reveal the nature of this flux ratio discrepancy, perhaps attributable to an ongoing microlensing event. The modelled unWISE magnitudes are similar for each component: W1, W2 = 14.94, 14.03 for A and W1, W2 \u00a0=\u00a015.08, 13.97 for B. We note that even though the WISE quasar fluxes should be unaffected by microlensing, they are likely contaminated by flux from the unmodelled lensing galaxy. Our simple mass model predicts a large magnification of \u223c20, however, this is unreliable since the potentially microlensing-affected flux ratio has been used to constrain the model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476752 id=\"129476752\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-9>5.2.9 J2014\u22123024</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This system was selected as a <em>Gaia</em> triple with W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.3. It was originally given a low priority because of the lack of a fourth image or lensing galaxy and a poor unWISE pixel model-only one component is classified as a quasar. We upgraded the priority given its selection by Delchambre et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), as in the case of J1817+2729. The spectra of the two eastern PSFs are blended and show features of a quasar at <em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span></em>\u00a0= 2.35, while the western PSF has a much redder spectrum, showing no quasar emission lines. Therefore, we can rule out the hypothesis that this is a quadruply imaged lensed quasar, but cannot rule out if the close pair are components of a doubly imaged quasar.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476754 id=\"129476754\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-10>5.2.10 J2032\u22122358</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the high airmass at which this target was observed, there is little signal from the blue arm. On the red arm, the single shared emission line can be identifed as Mg\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, since in one component there is the characteristic Mg\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption doublet. A corresponding signal can then be seen in the noisy blue spectra, corresponding to C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). This places the sources at <em><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span></em>\u00a0= 1.64, however, no lensing galaxy is detected in the Pan-STARRS images.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476756 id=\"129476756\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-11>5.2.11 J2145+6345</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This object was discovered by our W1\u2212W2\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.2, 4 <em>Gaia</em> detections search. Three spectra were extracted for this object, since components A and B could not be resolved. It has a similar configuration and brightness to PG1115+080 (Weymann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>). It lies at |<em>b</em>| \u00a0=\u00a07 in a crowded stellar field with a <em>Gaia</em> density of 71\u00a0000 detections per square degree. While such regions are normally excluded from lens searches, proper motions from <em>Gaia</em> made our search in such regions more manageable by removing many high proper motion contaminant systems. No galaxy is revealed in the PSF subtraction of the Pan-STARRS data. The system is very bright in WISE (W1 = 12.08 in Vega) and corresponds to a faint <em>ROSAT</em> source (Voges et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) with seven <em>ROSAT</em> photons within 30 arcsec of the lens. Furthermore, all images are optically bright (<em>G</em> \u00a0=\u00a016.86, 17.26, 18.34, and 18.56), making it second only to PSJ0147+4630 (Berghea et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) in terms of the brightest fourth image. This makes the system ideal for high-cadence, high signal-to-noise monitoring to determine time delays for cosmography (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Our mass model (SIE\u00a0+\u00a0shear) is constrained exclusively by image positions and fluxes, as the lensing galaxy is not detected. It predicts a shear of 0.13, \u221236 deg east of north, and an overall magnification of \u223c21. The fitted galaxy position is at x, y \u00a0=\u00a00.206, 0.271 arcsec relative to the astrometry given in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#app1\">A</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=129476758 id=\"129476758\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2-12>5.2.12 J2350+3654</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows a <em>gi</em> Hyper-Suprime Cam (HSC) colour image of J2350+3654. A third blue object, C, is seen north-east of the lensing galaxy. Subtraction of the lensing galaxy and quasar images reveals two more sources, one to the west of the lensing galaxy, and one red source west of image A, the brighter image. The <em>i</em>-band magnitudes of A, B, and C are 20.82, 21.10, and 21.9. There also exists narrow band (NB515) HSC imaging of this system. The differences in <em>g-i</em> and <em>g-NB515</em> colours between the three components are: \u0394(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>i</em>)<sub>AB, AC</sub>\u00a0= \u22120.08, \u22120.62, and \u0394(<em>g</em> \u2212 <em>NB</em>515)<sub>AB, AC</sub>\u00a0= 0.28, \u22120.09. The nature of C is still yet to be determined. It might be a third quasar image, but given the single lensing galaxy we would often expect a fourth image. It could also be a secondary source, such as the quasar host galaxy \u2013 as in SDSSJ1206+4332 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) \u2013 or another quasar. C could also be a foreground star. Deeper imaging and spectra of this system are required.</p>                        <a id=\"129476760\" scrollto-destination=\"129476760\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=mzGI6kymFby35QFc781MXb2agbA-LP1yJd3tennVYKWp4ICa9Ji2rdwxhgUYwSvkaEdbAOpch0bRLGWYp1hOMxS5iwG7VKEvRaVq35sNIiXigD3SAP2Sjr394xcqseehxH-2gI67-lc-kvr9rGGugzVYn6a84q058A1d6c6pvImE~D1RDJDdt8ZeWazXR97hw0GhdfKtxi7fjfOHpxgs~PbvspsrGziqdqjEpWcGWiTf6523lZmiVCBdgmfkCYybwpmy6kM4Dmrp9wrogTZqLmUaGLrHDpMBzC26QotR9YcU~QeAYcce9zJk~VxkL9KQw4k7R91PvzO4a92LG13Rwg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: A 7 x 7 arcsec gi HSC colour image of J2350+3654; middle: model for the confirmed quasar images (A and B) subtracted from the data; right: confirmed quasar and galaxy models subtracted from the data, revealing a bright blue point source and two other sources, one west of the lensing galaxy and one west of image A.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476760/sty3366fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476760\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=dJlV-5lZZQLvjRwnekW7D5Lo-U6SexWNRUafZJKV5NS8ak7EU1pWwcvZA7BpbEN4rcx2tuzt-kaPzBRMD0GPVSsOy07fSS9B~ITyCdMjhBlpAJaLvjCUO-IH~zio70Llx5PMYvFDRJfPjg9OP4pj63k45hkSVs1W1w7FOQQ6tfsKblS2SA6kOTlxSmYBOz0DgD6zbyHYZHGjBIxxkWOmYrYx3WTzSmyMvVI6IMSUB6sT9cK4j-BGEmoXcdqim5gKp1K5gNtc-H5NpRax~q1-KPVEiut7NSDBzT7PvoSS8FRxD2TgUXy7FANB80sAqaS8gzcEd6FlEuCg4LXueVypDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476760&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left</em>: A 7 x 7 arcsec <em>gi</em> HSC colour image of J2350+3654; <em>middle</em>: model for the confirmed quasar images (A and B) subtracted from the data; <em>right</em>: confirmed quasar and galaxy models subtracted from the data, revealing a bright blue point source and two other sources, one west of the lensing galaxy and one west of image A.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=mzGI6kymFby35QFc781MXb2agbA-LP1yJd3tennVYKWp4ICa9Ji2rdwxhgUYwSvkaEdbAOpch0bRLGWYp1hOMxS5iwG7VKEvRaVq35sNIiXigD3SAP2Sjr394xcqseehxH-2gI67-lc-kvr9rGGugzVYn6a84q058A1d6c6pvImE~D1RDJDdt8ZeWazXR97hw0GhdfKtxi7fjfOHpxgs~PbvspsrGziqdqjEpWcGWiTf6523lZmiVCBdgmfkCYybwpmy6kM4Dmrp9wrogTZqLmUaGLrHDpMBzC26QotR9YcU~QeAYcce9zJk~VxkL9KQw4k7R91PvzO4a92LG13Rwg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left: A 7 x 7 arcsec gi HSC colour image of J2350+3654; middle: model for the confirmed quasar images (A and B) subtracted from the data; right: confirmed quasar and galaxy models subtracted from the data, revealing a bright blue point source and two other sources, one west of the lensing galaxy and one west of image A.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476760/sty3366fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476760\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=dJlV-5lZZQLvjRwnekW7D5Lo-U6SexWNRUafZJKV5NS8ak7EU1pWwcvZA7BpbEN4rcx2tuzt-kaPzBRMD0GPVSsOy07fSS9B~ITyCdMjhBlpAJaLvjCUO-IH~zio70Llx5PMYvFDRJfPjg9OP4pj63k45hkSVs1W1w7FOQQ6tfsKblS2SA6kOTlxSmYBOz0DgD6zbyHYZHGjBIxxkWOmYrYx3WTzSmyMvVI6IMSUB6sT9cK4j-BGEmoXcdqim5gKp1K5gNtc-H5NpRax~q1-KPVEiut7NSDBzT7PvoSS8FRxD2TgUXy7FANB80sAqaS8gzcEd6FlEuCg4LXueVypDg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476760&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left</em>: A 7 x 7 arcsec <em>gi</em> HSC colour image of J2350+3654; <em>middle</em>: model for the confirmed quasar images (A and B) subtracted from the data; <em>right</em>: confirmed quasar and galaxy models subtracted from the data, revealing a bright blue point source and two other sources, one west of the lensing galaxy and one west of image A.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476761 id=\"129476761\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have observed 33 candidates identified amongst photometric quasar candidates with multiple <em>Gaia</em> detections, or a single <em>Gaia</em> detection offset from a galaxy. We have found 22 lenses, two highly probable lenses, and five NIQs. One candidate is still unclassified, and three are contaminant systems. For the two likely lenses, J0203+1612 shows two blue point sources either side of a galaxy, with a spectrum showing blended features of a low-redshift galaxy and a higher redshift quasar; J1307+0642 also shows two blue point sources either side of a bright galaxy, each corresponding to a resolved <em>Chandra</em> X-ray source. Our low contaminant rate arises from the large number of bright lenses left in the Pan-STARRS footprint (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) coupled with a large reduction in typical contaminant systems using <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s catalogue information and unWISE pixel modelling. This modelling has now become particularly useful due to the increase in resolution and detection of small-separation pairs in <em>Gaia</em> DR2. The limited spectroscopic follow-up time since the second <em>Gaia</em> data release has allowed us to concentrate on the lens candidates that are most convincing, namely those with bright lensing galaxies. To build a statistical sample from <em>Gaia</em>, however, we must ensure that the lensed quasars with fainter lensing galaxies are confirmed. We are confident that these have been selected in our candidate list, since our lens selection techniques recover all previously known lensed quasars with two or more <em>Gaia</em> detections, which includes statistical samples unbiased by bright lensing galaxies (e.g. SQLS).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We investigate the bias in our current sample of lenses discovered with <em>Gaia</em> \u2013 including the lenses discovered in paper II \u2013 by comparing to a complete sample of mock lenses that would have images detected by <em>Gaia</em> with image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> for details of the mock lens sample). Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows the lensing galaxy brightness against source redshift for the 26 lenses confirmed in this series of papers that satisfy the above criteria. Also overlaid is the mock sample, demonstrating that we are clearly biased towards lensed quasars with bright lensing galaxies, as expected. We note that the nearly identical quasar pairs identified throughout our campaign might partly represent the missing systems with fainter lens galaxies. Though deeper imaging is required to reveal potential lensing galaxies in these systems, we are still limited by lack of spectroscopic follow-up time to confirm candidates without obvious lensing galaxies in the relatively shallow Pan-STARRS imaging. A bias towards lower redshift sources is also present, explained both by the degeneracy with galaxy brightness and perhaps by prioritization of candidates showing a <em>u</em>-band excess when such data are available. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> also reveals that many lensed quasars detected by <em>Gaia</em> are expected to have faint lensing galaxies that would not be uncovered given the depth of current Pan-STARRS imaging. These lenses could be targetted by modelling deeper data, such as Dark Energy Survey data, or by looking for quasar pairs with similar variability within <em>Gaia</em> and/or LSST light curves.</p>                        <a id=\"129476764\" scrollto-destination=\"129476764\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=bvrpNsc67wPzAgvwTcy2AlOiZDuPLZFgZAudvHVyxbyeCrbN9xYn5spK8gFv2rht3bScQxCs4hIIZR1HkwJVfHSOCX3OOi-8qaZfI-aLqoGsbiCiqS4vOFgnF1XbdrsDBzL8k0KQWUCXKUKw039uGV1MxVDOurY-ljwl3k4iJk3UIxDYw8a8VLvrfmc-vB0BUHlCnIw4n2eZWa1QsXkWnX0DxpNc3s4htg~8mSqwyvJUvRIkBmRTRMpbbXRjIWrN1KE8uiDcxgTHMOzFVaKT6-DPJfjAL9m4ohZ3pc0pZZy7ja~CViVJP56vXowliIGARcLIy8V4OSEju3ATrajsyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plot of lensing galaxy i-band magnitude against source redshift for the 26 lensed quasars from this paper and paper II satisfying two Gaia detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles, or three for quads, and image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec. A complete mock sample with the same detection criteria is overlaid as black dots.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476764/sty3366fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476764\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=NdIjMy-7zaYuLVHtjxrAdQ0JSPl5BqClH2rnyVGft80S8UyDOBKyefYyKEkn3JUDhIpNV9TY3zPc~8sXjMVpoOKj6Y5bB7381qdYBHpndSX~45r2V0AlsMlg5Z6SvEkRG1gVN-PEO1JBeqXbEVys804nuCPrZyo5cdvdCxCVJI94t887G76IMFKZvG~8n8W2eBcyK8whuzAUHExnwTMavpmaEFQsR8O9zMvXMgCb2a5~pdMZDfNUf~ogYlUgbL2uM5mnYfPVqEgpqpIcFSO1AcpkQoL3cXPRXalQORl5LsCh2Hf~lv~J5t-cgx1OZjV7CVwkaPrp6fuBOgjjZL0U6Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476764&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plot of lensing galaxy <em>i</em>-band magnitude against source redshift for the 26 lensed quasars from this paper and paper II satisfying two <em>Gaia</em> detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles, or three for quads, and image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec. A complete mock sample with the same detection criteria is overlaid as black dots.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=bvrpNsc67wPzAgvwTcy2AlOiZDuPLZFgZAudvHVyxbyeCrbN9xYn5spK8gFv2rht3bScQxCs4hIIZR1HkwJVfHSOCX3OOi-8qaZfI-aLqoGsbiCiqS4vOFgnF1XbdrsDBzL8k0KQWUCXKUKw039uGV1MxVDOurY-ljwl3k4iJk3UIxDYw8a8VLvrfmc-vB0BUHlCnIw4n2eZWa1QsXkWnX0DxpNc3s4htg~8mSqwyvJUvRIkBmRTRMpbbXRjIWrN1KE8uiDcxgTHMOzFVaKT6-DPJfjAL9m4ohZ3pc0pZZy7ja~CViVJP56vXowliIGARcLIy8V4OSEju3ATrajsyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plot of lensing galaxy i-band magnitude against source redshift for the 26 lensed quasars from this paper and paper II satisfying two Gaia detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles, or three for quads, and image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec. A complete mock sample with the same detection criteria is overlaid as black dots.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476764/sty3366fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476764\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=NdIjMy-7zaYuLVHtjxrAdQ0JSPl5BqClH2rnyVGft80S8UyDOBKyefYyKEkn3JUDhIpNV9TY3zPc~8sXjMVpoOKj6Y5bB7381qdYBHpndSX~45r2V0AlsMlg5Z6SvEkRG1gVN-PEO1JBeqXbEVys804nuCPrZyo5cdvdCxCVJI94t887G76IMFKZvG~8n8W2eBcyK8whuzAUHExnwTMavpmaEFQsR8O9zMvXMgCb2a5~pdMZDfNUf~ogYlUgbL2uM5mnYfPVqEgpqpIcFSO1AcpkQoL3cXPRXalQORl5LsCh2Hf~lv~J5t-cgx1OZjV7CVwkaPrp6fuBOgjjZL0U6Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476764&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plot of lensing galaxy <em>i</em>-band magnitude against source redshift for the 26 lensed quasars from this paper and paper II satisfying two <em>Gaia</em> detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles, or three for quads, and image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec. A complete mock sample with the same detection criteria is overlaid as black dots.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> shows image separation versus source redshift for all known lensed quasars across the whole sky satisfying two or at least three <em>Gaia</em> detections for doubles and quads, respectively, <em>G</em> &lt; 20.7 for each detection, |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20, and image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec. This amounts to 96 such systems. We also plot the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> mock sample and histograms of the two parameters. The mock sample is normalized to the same area of sky in which the lenses are restricted to be. This shows that there are still \u223c200 bright lensed quasars at modest separation left to be discovered, with \u223c316 in total. These missing lenses are certainly being detected by <em>Gaia</em> since it detects all components of known lenses and pairs of point sources at these magnitudes and separations. The majority of these undiscovered lenses will be in the Southern hemisphere, as imaging and spectroscopic surveys for this area of sky are recent or yet to begin.</p>                        <a id=\"129476766\" scrollto-destination=\"129476766\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=gmzc-J6e-jht6J9iKJH-dESYq98PBSrtcwPYNue7LOrNOKcScM-T33VyMzQp2SfgjPCGHBxfZEKAkt28MlO~rUZwXJ5-tle16BhP1L~C7KEU1BmLNORC~IBlhx~ur0W-88jpzRis~GwfOdkJcHdd3P~Z-9QKu8EVBIY4X3vKMWJIWq7Edizuu3qr-Kas6ZNn32mjZMnw-SE76F6ks6N2g5X0IoHLLRNjLe3xJ59N3~s490rUlGViqMQjhoGoYoEICvObMqd9AV04aMKkq2dkCX7417EaEuZlbxtWIe7Kw7rjhaCOhoQzXF4ej2VGfD6VMPb05RhX0k~oPNi80EIB3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plot of image separation against source redshift for all known lensed quasars satisfying |b| &gt; 20, image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec, and two (at least three) Gaia detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles (quads). The image separations are in 0.2 arcsec bins and the source redshifts in 0.25 bins. The mocks are plotted with a frequency four\u00a0times that of the known lens area, since the OM10 catalogue is 100\u00a0000 deg2 and sky area outside of the galactic plane is 65.7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the full sky, i.e. 27\u00a0100 deg2. There are 96 known lenses that meet the stated criteria, while mocks predict 316 in total.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476766/sty3366fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476766\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=VG1fQlHTkJ-x5mPdkTGNX6rlCjqHEX3Avcw-0AtmtfxTMLOgaxSGQJ46lWjEhxCoatDb4N7krJZ-cprA9rkraYvr28GSIdZjU2fKINdftwm~GAtkzE8UNi4EFJw9sPKRDY1VfuzcyVfsGOCY6-HS4QOIxepQh1psBvtC-zl4x54S9UENPl-2nmYoSQ5Cj7NOGBso7pLZ5G1EbyUPBPLrjBf9NoQNceBNj~lihjrqNR652jOaTf7pXmLz-WzDKiI22CJIAFxvPNW9ovZ6nxxMQSRPxOOYUupHv~C5qJVGSReMcaL1wzs7tM~mhL3rhaGFntRVa3aUjbcpqC2~fEQSZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476766&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plot of image separation against source redshift for all known lensed quasars satisfying |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20, image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec, and two (at least three) <em>Gaia</em> detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles (quads). The image separations are in 0.2 arcsec bins and the source redshifts in 0.25 bins. The mocks are plotted with a frequency four\u00a0times that of the known lens area, since the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> catalogue is 100\u00a0000 deg<sup>2</sup> and sky area outside of the galactic plane is 65.7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the full sky, i.e. 27\u00a0100 deg<sup>2</sup>. There are 96 known lenses that meet the stated criteria, while mocks predict 316 in total.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=gmzc-J6e-jht6J9iKJH-dESYq98PBSrtcwPYNue7LOrNOKcScM-T33VyMzQp2SfgjPCGHBxfZEKAkt28MlO~rUZwXJ5-tle16BhP1L~C7KEU1BmLNORC~IBlhx~ur0W-88jpzRis~GwfOdkJcHdd3P~Z-9QKu8EVBIY4X3vKMWJIWq7Edizuu3qr-Kas6ZNn32mjZMnw-SE76F6ks6N2g5X0IoHLLRNjLe3xJ59N3~s490rUlGViqMQjhoGoYoEICvObMqd9AV04aMKkq2dkCX7417EaEuZlbxtWIe7Kw7rjhaCOhoQzXF4ej2VGfD6VMPb05RhX0k~oPNi80EIB3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plot of image separation against source redshift for all known lensed quasars satisfying |b| &gt; 20, image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec, and two (at least three) Gaia detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles (quads). The image separations are in 0.2 arcsec bins and the source redshifts in 0.25 bins. The mocks are plotted with a frequency four\u00a0times that of the known lens area, since the OM10 catalogue is 100\u00a0000 deg2 and sky area outside of the galactic plane is 65.7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the full sky, i.e. 27\u00a0100 deg2. There are 96 known lenses that meet the stated criteria, while mocks predict 316 in total.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476766/sty3366fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476766\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=VG1fQlHTkJ-x5mPdkTGNX6rlCjqHEX3Avcw-0AtmtfxTMLOgaxSGQJ46lWjEhxCoatDb4N7krJZ-cprA9rkraYvr28GSIdZjU2fKINdftwm~GAtkzE8UNi4EFJw9sPKRDY1VfuzcyVfsGOCY6-HS4QOIxepQh1psBvtC-zl4x54S9UENPl-2nmYoSQ5Cj7NOGBso7pLZ5G1EbyUPBPLrjBf9NoQNceBNj~lihjrqNR652jOaTf7pXmLz-WzDKiI22CJIAFxvPNW9ovZ6nxxMQSRPxOOYUupHv~C5qJVGSReMcaL1wzs7tM~mhL3rhaGFntRVa3aUjbcpqC2~fEQSZQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476766&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plot of image separation against source redshift for all known lensed quasars satisfying |<em>b</em>| &gt; 20, image separations between 1 and 4 arcsec, and two (at least three) <em>Gaia</em> detections brighter than 20.7 for doubles (quads). The image separations are in 0.2 arcsec bins and the source redshifts in 0.25 bins. The mocks are plotted with a frequency four\u00a0times that of the known lens area, since the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> catalogue is 100\u00a0000 deg<sup>2</sup> and sky area outside of the galactic plane is 65.7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the full sky, i.e. 27\u00a0100 deg<sup>2</sup>. There are 96 known lenses that meet the stated criteria, while mocks predict 316 in total.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To manage the rapidly increasing number of lensed quasars (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>), we have created an online data base that will be kept up-to-date with all known lensed quasars. Each lens has multiband imaging cutouts, a variety of catalogue information, and relevant survey links.</p>                        <a id=\"129476768\" scrollto-destination=\"129476768\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=BwJQ9GA-dakTWSqo0-OitQwuqtkydViLQY9CJsDJ0V9fpBX3fpToZBwKmtvG-274RyTmcNqrDu4BryB0xMQHvl8Zrn7cEZSkk~9j4PQYmhAi6Kj-17CS2WFcf~tmfpf5AAGakiMKk50Fvxz1qd-4PJKJdr4GcpYg6m2RuAK3vqByJWEv78uSeuhKnu~CnJEGXBbKxGcdVnnDuN8oN1YweDIjUSyA8AkT3jbKzAvAvtZAzgqBXf0lZRbyQC01hQPReGm~FcF6UNlHpLnF-XSjzNuoJkagFrsGBbXcANppRtacQ-0TPHecSCKUS20EWhhYVANyoHA5MOpzUvrUys-xrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Number of published lensed quasars discovered each year, split into doubles and quads.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476768/sty3366fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476768\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=L211tgFyfNVSTRYkgWhGOJLlV60MP3nOJZzOLWJh2sxsr882ZsiG5WUj1r4xr~xDReagMGqlIp~Xzt2U3ObR5l3Bp9OTzNPkouYG~fCNooC1r73QjX1CKBttk-nOTrEHfMYTScFvlXdCw2odGqAgUAHd2qFoXrn0GJVxZQ2KXioj3VTc1OGMrQjeRiAIaBZBNSBl9HQTdYNhlSNEmhZYSG4TVzorga2hsBZvtCCK7XAWS64Uugb3ddh03-w9L7cBg-vPmzwj21~zTBoqZOCKoIAjlgk1RRX8UuGpSonyvVSA6BIFWNkXpw3WrF4QKnxLZRaH5upVm2Mf612D4xU0fw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476768&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Number of published lensed quasars discovered each year, split into doubles and quads.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/m_sty3366fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&amp;Signature=BwJQ9GA-dakTWSqo0-OitQwuqtkydViLQY9CJsDJ0V9fpBX3fpToZBwKmtvG-274RyTmcNqrDu4BryB0xMQHvl8Zrn7cEZSkk~9j4PQYmhAi6Kj-17CS2WFcf~tmfpf5AAGakiMKk50Fvxz1qd-4PJKJdr4GcpYg6m2RuAK3vqByJWEv78uSeuhKnu~CnJEGXBbKxGcdVnnDuN8oN1YweDIjUSyA8AkT3jbKzAvAvtZAzgqBXf0lZRbyQC01hQPReGm~FcF6UNlHpLnF-XSjzNuoJkagFrsGBbXcANppRtacQ-0TPHecSCKUS20EWhhYVANyoHA5MOpzUvrUys-xrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Number of published lensed quasars discovered each year, split into doubles and quads.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/129476768/sty3366fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"129476768\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/3/10.1093_mnras_sty3366/1/sty3366fig12.jpeg?Expires=1611465343&Signature=L211tgFyfNVSTRYkgWhGOJLlV60MP3nOJZzOLWJh2sxsr882ZsiG5WUj1r4xr~xDReagMGqlIp~Xzt2U3ObR5l3Bp9OTzNPkouYG~fCNooC1r73QjX1CKBttk-nOTrEHfMYTScFvlXdCw2odGqAgUAHd2qFoXrn0GJVxZQ2KXioj3VTc1OGMrQjeRiAIaBZBNSBl9HQTdYNhlSNEmhZYSG4TVzorga2hsBZvtCCK7XAWS64Uugb3ddh03-w9L7cBg-vPmzwj21~zTBoqZOCKoIAjlgk1RRX8UuGpSonyvVSA6BIFWNkXpw3WrF4QKnxLZRaH5upVm2Mf612D4xU0fw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=129476768&ar=5237725&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3366fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Number of published lensed quasars discovered each year, split into doubles and quads.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476769 id=\"129476769\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented the discovery of 22 new gravitationally lensed quasars with resolved spectra from ISIS on the WHT. Two lens candidates are very likely to be lensed quasars, however we have not been able to obtain spatially resolved spectra of the components. In total, we obtained a 70\u201390\u00a0per\u2009cent success rate in confirming gravitationally lensed quasars, while several candidates require deeper observations to understand their nature. The particularly low contaminant rate from a purely photometric selection arises from our ability to remove contaminants using <em>Gaia</em> catalogue information and modelling of unWISE pixels.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens sample presented here and Lemon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) is clearly a biased and incomplete sample, missing lensed quasars with fainter lensing galaxies and/or higher source redshifts. We have over 30 high-quality candidates left to follow-up that will begin to fill this missing parameter space. Future <em>Gaia</em> data releases will help confirm these lenses efficiently via more precise proper motion measurements, autocorrelation searches based on <em>Gaia</em> light curves, and 2D PSF reconstruction techniques to search for lensing galaxies directly in the <em>Gaia</em> data (Harrison <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Building a complete sample of lensed quasars from <em>Gaia</em> at modest image separation (&gt;1 arcsec) and from uncrowded fields (|<em>b</em>| &gt; 20 across the whole sky) will provide a useful statistical sample of around 350 lensed quasars, an order of magnitude greater than SQLS, which can be used to impose constraints on cosmological parameters and massive galaxy evolution (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Finet\u00a0&amp; Surdej <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). We presently only know of approximately 100 lensed quasars in this sample, so an effort must be made to confirm the remaining systems.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476773 id=\"129476773\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We would like to thank Elm\u00e9 Breedt for her support with observations at the WHT, Paul Schechter for sharing his modelling of J1817+2729 and convincing us to observe the quad system, and Edi Rusu for helpful discussion regarding J1537\u22123010 and J1817+2729. We would also like to thank Patrick Hall for suggesting an updated redshift for J1418\u22121610. CAL and RGM would like to thank the STFC, and MWA acknowledges support from the STFC in the form of an Ernest Rutherford Fellowship. This work has used data from the European Space Agency (ESA) mission <em>Gaia</em> (<a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/gaia</a>), processed by the <em>Gaia</em> Data Processing and Analysis Consortium (DPAC, <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium\" target=\"_blank\">https://www.cosmos.esa.int/web/gaia/dpac/consortium</a>). Funding for the DPAC has been provided by national institutions, in particular the institutions participating in the <em>Gaia</em> Multilateral Agreement. This publication uses data products from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=129476775 id=\"129476775\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    Gravitationally lensed quasars in <em>Gaia</em> \u2013 III. 22 new lensed quasars () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div
